<QuestionSource url="https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/bulletins/consumerpriceinflation/latest">
# Summary of UK Consumer Price Inflation Article (December 2025)

## Key Statistics and Facts:

### Annual Inflation Rates (December 2025):
- **CPIH (Consumer Prices Index including owner occupiers' housing costs): 3.6%** (up from 3.5% in November 2025)
- **CPI (Consumer Prices Index): 3.4%** (up from 3.2% in November 2025)
- **Core CPIH (excluding energy, food, alcohol and tobacco): 3.5%** (unchanged from November 2025)
- **Core CPI: 3.2%** (unchanged from November 2025)

### Monthly Changes (December 2025):
- CPIH rose 0.4% month-on-month (compared to 0.3% in December 2024)
- CPI rose 0.4% month-on-month (compared to 0.3% in December 2024)

### 2025 Annual Inflation Trajectory:
The article provides monthly CPIH rates throughout 2025:
- January: 3.9%
- February: 3.7%
- March: 3.4%
- April: 4.1%
- May: 4.0%
- June: 4.1%
- July: 4.2%
- August: 4.1%
- September: 4.1%
- October: 3.8%
- November: 3.5%
- December: 3.6%

### Component Breakdown (12-month rates to December 2025):
- Food and non-alcoholic beverages: 4.5% (up from 4.2% in November)
- Alcohol and tobacco: 5.2% (up from 4.0% in November)
- Transport: 4.0% (up from 3.7% in November)
- Housing and household services: 4.6% (down from 4.8% in November)
- Owner occupiers' housing costs: 4.2% (down from 4.5% in November) - lowest since May 2023
- Education: 7.6% (unchanged)
- Restaurants and hotels: 3.8% (up from 3.5%)
- All goods: 2.2% (up from 2.1%)
- All services: 4.5% (unchanged)

### Main Drivers of December 2025 Inflation Change:
- **Alcohol and tobacco**: Largest upward contribution, driven by tobacco duty increase on November 26, 2025 (timing difference from 2024 when it was increased October 30)
- **Transport**: Second-largest upward contribution, primarily from air fares (rose 28.6% in December 2025 vs. 16.2% in December 2024)
- **Motor fuels**: Negligible effect - petrol averaged 136.3 pence/litre (same as year earlier); diesel averaged 145.7 pence/litre (up from 142.6 pence/litre)

### Housing Cost Trends:
- OOH costs contribution to annual CPIH: 0.71 percentage points (smallest since May 2023, decreased for 11 consecutive months from peak of 1.31 percentage points in January 2025)
- Rents contribution: 0.23 percentage points (last lower in May 2022)

## Context:
This data comes from the UK Office for National Statistics (ONS) official bulletin on consumer price inflation for December 2025, which is the authoritative source specified in the resolution criteria for the forecasting question.
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/bulletins/consumerpriceinflation/latest#notable-movements-in-prices">
# Summary of UK Consumer Price Inflation Article (December 2025)

## Key Statistics and Facts:

### Annual Inflation Rates (December 2025):
- **CPIH (Consumer Prices Index including owner occupiers' housing costs): 3.6%** (up from 3.5% in November 2025)
- **CPI (Consumer Prices Index): 3.4%** (up from 3.2% in November 2025)
- **Core CPIH (excluding energy, food, alcohol and tobacco): 3.5%** (unchanged from November 2025)
- **Core CPI: 3.2%** (unchanged from November 2025)

### Monthly Changes (December 2025):
- CPIH rose 0.4% month-on-month (compared to 0.3% rise in December 2024)
- CPI rose 0.4% month-on-month (compared to 0.3% rise in December 2024)

### 2025 Annual Inflation Trajectory:
The article provides monthly CPIH rates throughout 2025:
- January: 3.9%
- February: 3.7%
- March: 3.4%
- April: 4.1%
- May: 4.0%
- June: 4.1%
- July: 4.2%
- August: 4.1%
- September: 4.1%
- October: 3.8%
- November: 3.5%
- December: 3.6%

### Component Breakdown (12-month rates to December 2025):
- Food and non-alcoholic beverages: 4.5% (up from 4.2% in November)
- Alcohol and tobacco: 5.2% (up from 4.0% in November)
- Transport: 4.0% (up from 3.7% in November)
- Housing and household services: 4.6% (down from 4.8% in November)
- Owner occupiers' housing costs: 4.2% (down from 4.5% in November) - lowest since May 2023
- Education: 7.6% (unchanged)
- Restaurants and hotels: 3.8% (up from 3.5%)
- All goods: 2.2% (up from 2.1%)
- All services: 4.5% (unchanged)

### Main Drivers of December 2025 Inflation Change:
- **Alcohol and tobacco**: Largest upward contribution, driven by tobacco duty increase on November 26, 2025
- **Transport**: Second-largest upward contribution, primarily from air fares (rose 28.6% in December 2025)
- **Motor fuels**: Negligible effect; petrol averaged 136.3 pence per litre (same as year earlier), diesel averaged 145.7 pence per litre (up from 142.6 pence)

### Housing Costs:
- OOH costs contribution to annual CPIH: 0.71 percentage points (smallest since May 2023, down from 1.31 percentage points in January 2025)
- Rents contribution: 0.23 percentage points (last lower in May 2022)
- Housing and household services made the largest contribution to CPIH for the 18th consecutive month (1.37 percentage points)

**Note**: This is official ONS data for December 2025, which directly addresses the resolution criteria for the forecasting question regarding UK inflation under Liz Truss's leadership (though the article itself does not mention political leadership or attribute inflation outcomes to any specific Prime Minister).
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://www.ons.gov.uk/employmentandlabourmarket/peopleinwork/employmentandemployeetypes/bulletins/averageweeklyearningsingreatbritain/latest#main-points-for-march-to-may-2022">
# Summary of ONS Article: Average Weekly Earnings in Great Britain (January 2026)

## Key Statistics and Facts

**Earnings Growth (September to November 2025):**
- Annual growth in regular earnings (excluding bonuses): 4.5%
- Annual growth in total earnings (including bonuses): 4.7%
- Average weekly earnings in November 2025: £741 for total earnings, £689 for regular earnings

**Real Earnings Growth (adjusted for CPIH inflation):**
- Real regular pay growth: 0.6%
- Real total pay growth: 0.8%

**Real Earnings Growth (adjusted for CPI inflation):**
- Real regular pay growth: 0.9%
- Real total pay growth: 1.1%

**Inflation Rate:**
- CPIH (Consumer Prices Index including owner occupiers' housing costs) averaged 3.8% for September to November 2025

**Sector-Specific Growth:**
- Public sector annual regular earnings growth: 7.9% (affected by base effects from pay rises paid earlier in 2025 than in 2024)
- Private sector annual regular earnings growth: 3.6%
- Public sector annual total earnings growth: 7.8%
- Private sector annual total earnings growth: 3.9%

**Industry-Specific Growth:**
- Wholesaling, retailing, hotels and restaurants sector: 5.1% regular annual growth (strongest after public sector)
- Finance and business services sector: 2.2% regular annual growth (lowest)

## Methodological Notes

- Data comes from the Monthly Wages and Salaries Survey (MWSS), sampling around 9,000 employers covering approximately 12.8 million employees in Great Britain
- Survey response rate for November 2025: 88.5%
- AWE is calculated as the ratio of estimated total pay for the whole economy divided by total number of employees
- AWE does not adjust for compositional changes in the workforce (e.g., full-time vs. part-time workers)

## Relevant Context

The article notes that an error was identified in inflation measures for April 2025 related to Vehicle Excise Duty, which overstated transport figures and some higher-level aggregates. This error was not revised per established policies but would have minimal impact on real measures of earnings for April 2025.
</QuestionSource>

<QuestionSource url="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/jul/11/britain-new-pm-5-september-tory-leadership-rules-announced">
# Summary of Article: "Britain to have new PM by 5 September as Tory leadership rules announced"

**Source:** The Guardian  
**Date:** July 11, 2022  
**Author:** Aubrey Allegretti

## Key Facts and Timeline:

- **New PM announcement date:** September 5, 2022
- **Leadership race timeline:** Final two candidates to be decided by end of Thursday the following week (July 21, 2022), with knockout votes beginning Wednesday afternoon (July 13, 2022)
- **Entry requirements:** Candidates need 20 MP backers to enter (increased from 8), and at least 30 votes to pass the first round

## Candidate Support Levels (as of July 11, 2022):

- **Rishi Sunak:** Nearly 40 MPs backing him
- **Penny Mordaunt:** 24 MPs (polling showed she was preferred candidate among party members according to Conservative Home)
- **Tom Tugendhat:** Third highest number of backers
- **Suella Braverman:** 12 MPs
- **Grant Shapps:** 8 MPs (fewest public supporters)

## Economic Policy Positions:

**Rishi Sunak:**
- Plans to warn that rivals' tax-cutting promises will fuel inflation
- Emphasizes need to deal with deficit ahead of major tax rises
- Hints at possible further public spending cuts
- Will say: "We need a return to traditional Conservative economic values – and that means honesty and responsibility, not fairy tales"

**Tom Tugendhat:**
- Pledges "10-year plan for growth"
- Argues tax cuts should be directed towards stimulating investment
- States: "Tax cuts cannot be the only round in the magazine to fire growth in the economy"

**Nadhim Zahawi:**
- Promises to cut income tax from 20p to 19p next year, and to 18p in 2024
- Pledges: "Tax as a percentage of GDP will fall year on year if I become prime minister"
- Would suspend all VAT and green levies on energy bills for two years
- Plans to finance tax cuts by getting every government department to cut costs by 20% (later qualified as reducing headcount rather than departmental spending)

**Jeremy Hunt:**
- Pledged to spend 3% of GDP on defence by 2027/28

## Political Context:

- Multiple candidates on the right competing for votes, described by sources as a "fight on the right"
- Labour leader Keir Starmer condemned the rush to cut taxes among Tory candidates, calling it an "arms race of fantasy economics"

**Note:** This article focuses on the leadership race mechanics and candidate positioning rather than specific inflation forecasts or economic analysis.
</QuestionSource>
